div.p: 5. III.45. Wednesday— Charles left us— Ride

Cabinet Meeting— The question now to be considered was the course to be pursued with regard to General Scott— On the claim to be the Senior Major-General, by virtue of his brevet to Major General Macomb, he has actually disobeyed his orders N. 109. and 110— He has professed disobedience ever since the appointment of Macomb, but until now he had indirectly caused all the orders to be executed, though professing to disobey them— The Attorney General being absent this Meeting was merely for first discussion— The measure which I proposed for consideration was that of only revoking General Scott’s Brevet— But the opinion was unanimous that this measure should not now be adopted. General Porter had prepared a draught of a Letter from him to Scott containing the reasons upon which his claim to command Macomb cannot be allowed, and upon which his disobedience must be exacted— General Porter had shewn me this Letter before, and now read to me an additional paragraphs in which my views were presented of the 62d. Article of War— I desired him to read my observations upon Scott’s claim and take from them any argument which he might think proper to add to his Letter— Mr Clay and Mr Rush expressed doubts of the expediency of revoking the brevet only. They appeared to think it would be better to dismiss him at once from the army— It was also urged by Mr Clay that the final measure should be postponed on account of the present doubtful prospect of the Presidential Election; of the loss of which I have myself no doubt— Mr Southard was for acting in Scott’s case without much delay— He thought that if any of these orders from Macomb which Scott circulates only through his Aide de Camp, should be disobeyed by any Officer of his division, they could not be sustained and vindicated as lawful orders— The members of the Administration are to read my Observations on Scott’s claim and on Mr Wirt’s return from Baltimore we are to have another Meeting.
